ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

GOVERNMENT-OWNED AND GOVERNMENT-LINKED COMPANIES

(Acquisitions and investments)


    1. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Finance who advises Government-owned and Government-linked companies on acquisitions and investments.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, Government-linked companies, like all other companies, have their own managements and boards of directors and they decide on acquisitions and investments. If necessary, they may seek the advice of investment banks or consultants.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): May I ask the Minister, particularly in the case which we were discussing yesterday when Question Time came to an end, in regard to Micropolis, from whom did this company seek any advice, if it did, that is, before Singapore Technologies acquired Micropolis?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Although I could not finish the Oral Answer in Parliament, I think the full answer has been circulated to all Members, including Mr Jeyaretnam. And just to recap, they consulted their own investment bankers and professional consultants before the decision was made, and this was made clear in my answer.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I know who finally makes the decision for Singapore Technologies?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Can I suggest that he reads my answer? It is the Board of Singapore Technologies.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May we know from the Minister: is the Cabinet at all informed or consulted before Government-owned and Government-linked companies take over or acquire other businesses?

Column: 143



    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The answer is no. In a general response to his question, there is a Ministerial Committee set up to oversee very large investments exceeding $500 million acquisitions, and this is chaired by DPM Lee, Minister for Finance is a member of the Committee, DPM Tony Tan is also a member, the Minister for Trade and Industry and BG Yeo are also members. But this Committee only concerns itself with very large acquisitions of $500 million or more and particularly with reference to overseas investments where there may be political overtones. Other than that, the companies themselves have their own boards and they are responsible for making their own decisions on a commercial basis. It is not feasible for Government to nanny every company it owns. Do not forget that Temasek Holdings, which is a Government-holding company, has shareholders' funds totalling $34 billion, and it is making profits averaging $1.6 billion per year over the last 10 years and it includes a huge stable of companies of large size, eg, SIA, DBS, and so forth, and they all have responsible boards who take investment decisions on their own after consulting with their professional advisers.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister on the issue of Micropolis. The loss, I believe, in the reply he gave me yesterday, amounts to about half a billion dollars. I would like to ask whether any of these is coming from CPF or is it some other source that has drawn into our reserves.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The answer is no. The acquisition was funded from ST's internal resources plus bank loans. So CPF is not involved.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister whether after it was decided to wind up Micropolis, a statement was made or a report was submitted to this Ministerial Committee to examine the acquisition of Micropolis by Singapore Technologies?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The position has been reviewed by the holding company, which is Temasek Holdings, and that is where the matter rests. No report has been made to Cabinet, nor is it required.

Column: 144



    Mr Jeyaretnam: It may not be required. But if you have a Ministerial Committee, is it not the function of the Ministerial Committee, chaired as he said by BG Lee, to inquire closely into huge losses suffered by Government-owned companies? Here we have a case of half a billion dollars gone down the drain.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The Ministerial Committee, as I explained earlier, is basically responsible for making acquisitions and would of course be interested in the details of any major losses which Temasek would in due course, after their own study, advise. However, I would like to point out that although in absolute terms, the loss looks very large, the sizes of the operations are also huge and our companies anyway are venturing into the high-tech areas. I think you should realise that the nature of the business is highly volatile and very capital-intensive, and if you are going to be in that business at all, you have to accept the consequences. I will refer you to a report - I think it was yesterday or before yesterday's papers - about Seagate, the largest disk drive company in the world, incurring a first quarter loss of over US$300 million because of the downturn in this business. So the nature of business requires high risk, you make money, you lose money. But overall, Temasek group of companies has been accumulating assets at a rate of, as I mentioned earlier, $1.6 billion per year over the last 10 years and without drawing on Government's equity.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: A final question, Mr Speaker, Sir. Is the Minister saying then that even if there is a high risk, Government-owned companies will still go into the acquisition or take-over, in the hope that they can turn round the company and make profits? We are dealing with people's money. The companies are trustees.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: That is the nature of a business decision. Either you do it or you don't. Would he like to suggest an alternative? Perhaps he would like to vet every decision made by Government companies.

Column: 145



    Mr Jeyaretnam: I should have thought that was obvious. There should be a proper committee, not chaired just by Ministers but also by public people who know about investments, to advise the Government-owned companies and Government-linked companies on acquisitions and take-overs.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: People like himself who knows about business investments?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: I would ask the Minister not to be personal.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: No. What I am saying is ---

    Mr Jeyaretnam: I am saying you could, could you not? You have BG Lee and his wife, I take it, is the Chairman of the Board ---

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Jeyaretnam, I thought you said that was your final question. Have you any other questions? If not, Dr Lee.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): Is it correct then to assume that except for these very large investments of over $500 million, to all intents and purposes, Government-linked companies run and operate like commercial companies in the private sector?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Indeed, that must be the case.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister whether he would give an assurance to the House that despite Micropolis, the Government will not get cold feet and will go on investing where there is a possibility that the public fund will benefit from investment, because there is a perception that because of Micropolis, the Government may get cold feet. I would like to have an assurance to this House by the Minister that despite Micropolis, he will make sound investment where he thinks it will benefit the economy.

Column: 146



    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: We do not take fright from Members' criticisms.

    Mr Inderjit Singh: One final question. From the lesson that we have learned from Micropolis, have we put in place any additional safeguards to ensure that such future problems are avoided, although I do support that we should continue to participate in these high-risk, high-return types of investments?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I am afraid there are no safeguards against business risks. You have to make your judgement and take your punishment or your rewards accordingly. I would just like to remind him that in assessing Singapore's investments, whether you lose or gain, you take a long view. I have said again and again that over the last 10 years, in aggregate, the companies have made substantial profits and added to Government's coffers. That should ultimately be the criteria, not criticisms or critics on individual investments.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Is there a sense now, because of what happened with Micropolis, that Government-linked companies are subject to greater public accountability and public scrutiny than private sector companies?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Indeed, this must be the sense and therefore I would assume that the management of these companies would take this into account. It must be so. In fact, it acts as a check of sorts that they are aware that they are dealing with public money. It makes them a little more cautious and it also may make them more risk-averse.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Is it not there in a sense then a sort of fundamental dilemma with Government-linked companies because, on the one hand, you do want them to be publicly accountable and, on the other hand, you do want them to be entrepreneurial, and for that you would indeed have to take risk, and when you take risk, there is indeed a risk of failure?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Indeed, that is true. There is a fundamental dilemma. In fact, a desirable outcome would be for the Government to divest itself fully of

Column: 147

companies with commercial activities, and that is still our intention over the long term. But many of our new companies, particularly the statutory boards which are being privatised, require a period of nurturing, so to speak, before they are let loose completely. But over time, companies, like SIA, DBS, other than policy considerations, should be entirely privatised. And this still remains our long term objective.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: If indeed that is the longer term objective, would it be possible for the Minister to outline what actually are the criteria for these companies to be divested? Perhaps then they could be divested earlier because these criteria can be satisfied.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The only companies which Government would want to retain de facto controlling interest are defence-related companies. Other than that, the other purely commercial companies have not been divested completely over the years because of their huge size. It would be very difficult to unload Government shareholdings overnight without disrupting the market.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: If it is because of the huge size, would it not be possible actually to break them down into small bits, so that the private sector can then chew on them?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Yes and no. How do we break Singapore Telecom or Singapore Power into little bits? We can do it within limits, but to divide a company as huge as Singapore Telecom into little bits so that they become more digestible may not be very easy.

Column: 147

GOVERNMENT-OWNED AND GOVERNMENT-LINKED COMPANIES
(Annual accounts of investments to Parliament)


    2. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Finance why there are no accounts made available to Parliament annually of all investments made by Government-owned and Government-linked companies.

Column: 148



    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The Government is not required under existing legislation to present the accounts of the Government-owned and Government-linked companies to Parliament.

    The Government-owned and Government-linked companies are set up under the Companies Act. Like all companies, they operate on a commercial basis, and have to respond and react quickly to changes in the business environment. It would therefore be difficult for these companies to operate if they were to be made accountable to Parliament for their every action. Like any other companies, they are subject to the same reporting and disclosure requirements under the Companies Act.

    In addition, companies which are listed on the Stock Exchange are accountable to their shareholders for their performance and operations. They have to circulate their annual reports to their shareholders.

    Strategic companies which are owned by the Government, such as Temasek Holdings and Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, are included in the Fifth Schedule of the Constitution. These companies are subject to the provisions of the Elected President in the use of their accumulated reserves. They are also required to submit yearly financial statements to the President.

    The existing system is adequate in monitoring the investments and performance of the Government-owned and Government-linked companies, and we should not make it unnecessarily more onerous for them to operate as purely commercial entities.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister how does this answer reconcile with his earlier answer on Micropolis about the accountability of Government-owned companies because they are dealing with public funds?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I do not see the contradiction in it. These companies are commercial companies. They have their own reporting requirements. Just because they incur a loss, are we going to change their reporting relationships?

Column: 149



    Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Minister not realise that the taxpayers remain in the position of shareholders of these companies because it is their monies, and is there not a duty to report to Parliament?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: As I explained before, it is the overall returns which we should be concerned with, not individual companies. What is the objective of reporting just pure losses without taking into consideration the overall profitability of these companies? To make sure that they do not operate as companies at all? Should we just get rid of them? When you are running a business, I assume that Mr Jeyaretnam has never run a business, ---

    Mr Jeyaretnam: No, I have not.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Exactly. This is the problem. He does not really understand business and that is precisely why he asked the question.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: But I am concerned with protecting the public's monies.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Protecting the public's monies is the function of the Government, and the Government is adding to its reserves every year. That is the best way of protecting it, not the way that you are suggesting.

    Dr Toh See Kiat (Aljunied): I would like to ask the Minister whether it is not true that some kind of reporting has already been made to the Public Accounts Committee of this House.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Indeed, that is true.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: He talks about overall reporting. Is there any overall reporting to Parliament?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Government accounts are presented to Parliament every year. You are quite free to question it. The Budget is coming up. Why do you not do your homework and ask proper questions at the proper time?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Is the Minister saying that the accounts of these Government-owned companies are reflected in the Budget?

Column: 150



    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The accounts of the companies are reported in their annual reports. Please read them.

Column: 150

SECOND CAUSEWAY
(Agreement on scale of fees)


    3. Mr Zulkifli bin Baharudin asked the Minister for Communications whether there are any agreements between the Singapore and Malaysian governments on the scale of fees to be charged to motorists using the second causeway and whether the Singapore Government had considered the amount of fees to be charged when the decision was made to construct the second causeway.

    The Minister of State for Communications (Dr John Chen Seow Phun) (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Inter-Government Agreement (IGA) for the Construction of the Second Crossing, each government may independently levy any toll on vehicles using it.

    The Second Crossing is a project jointly developed by Singapore and Malaysia. We had no specific tolls in mind when we decided to construct the Second Crossing. Malaysia has announced that it would be collecting toll from motorists using the Second Crossing. Singapore has also announced that it will do the same. For a start, we will peg our toll rates to Malaysia's toll charges.

    We hope that Malaysia will decide on tolls that are fair and reasonable taking into consideration the investment in the bridge and its ancillary facilities, as well as the need to optimise traffic flow across the Second Crossing as well as the Causeway.

    Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin (Nominated Member): I would like to ask the Minister of State whether, in view of the poor reception of motorists and businessmen in Singapore, he has made any representation to the Malaysian authorities to ensure a more rational and feasible fee structure for the use of the Second Causeway.

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have made known to the Malaysians that we will match their toll rates

Column: 151

and I have also commented publicly that the Malaysian rates, as reported by the press, were too high and expressed the hope that they be lowered. So let us wait for their announcement.

    Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin: In view of the expression by some motorists that they may not want to use the Second Crossing and there could possibly be more congestion on the existing Causeway and the likelihood that the Second Crossing may not be utilised and become a white elephant, has the Minister of State considered plans whereby this will not happen?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, this is also our concern and this is why I said publicly that we hope the rates would be reasonable. We have not finalised the rates. So we will have to look at what the actual rates are and, as I said, initially we will match the rates and we will decide later on what the rates would be in order to optimise traffic flow.

    Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin: I am sure that the Singapore Government has its own reasons for proceeding in the first place to build the Second Crossing and I am very sure that the interests of motorists and Singaporeans are consistent with this objective. But if the Malaysian government were to consider not imposing more feasible charges for the Second Crossing, would he consider imposing different charges for Singaporeans and Malaysians using the Second Crossing?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, when we determine the toll rates, we have to look at two considerations: the investment made by the Singapore Government and also the traffic objective. Since it is a joint project, it is in our interest to make it successful. And I am sure it is also in their interest to make it successful. So let us do not prejudge that it would not be a successful project. We are hopeful that it would be successful.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Could the Minister of State please inform the House at what stage did the Singapore Government

Column: 152

convey to the Malaysian Government that they would match the toll rates charged by them?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Both at the official level and also in our public comments. I think Mr Lim Boon Heng said that. I have said that in public also.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: My question is: at what point, or at what stage, was it very early on?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: The agreement was that each government would set the rates independently although a joint committee was set up very early, I think, in 1994. The discussions were on various aspects, but the actual discussion on the rates itself was only in the last few months.

    Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin: I would like to ask the Minister of State whether he would consider imposing similar charges for the First and Second Causeways to ensure that both Causeways are fully utilised.

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: That is one possibility but we have not finalised yet.

Column: 152

HDB EXECUTIVE FLATS IN NORTH-EAST ZONE
(Selling price)


    4. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for National Development (a) why is the selling price of executive flats in the North-East Zone for the first quarter of 1998, as announced by the Housing and Development Board (HDB), lower by more than $12,000 compared to the last quarter whilst at the same time the selling prices of four-room and five-room flats are increased by $8,200 and $9,100 respectively; and (b) what contributed to the much higher selling price of HDB flats in the North-East Zone compared to other zones.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the prices of new HDB flats vary according to the location, floor area, design features and finishes. In addition, factors like good

Column: 153

view, proximity to MRT/LRT stations and commercial centres, etc, are also considered in the pricing of the flats.

    Let me first explain the price differences for the 4-room and 5-room flats in the 1st quarter 1998 compared to the 4th quarter 1997. In the 4th Quarter 1997, only flats from Sengkang were available for booking whereas in the 1st Quarter of 1998, flats from both Sengkang and Hougang Towns are being offered for booking. As Hougang is a more developed town with more established amenities than Sengkang, the selling prices of the new flats in Hougang are higher than those in Sengkang. This accounts for the slightly higher average selling prices of the new 4-room and 5-room flats in this zone in the 1st Quarter 1998 offer.

    As for the Executive flats, those in Sengkang that were offered for booking in the 4th Quarter 1997 are located closer to the proposed Sengkang MRT station and Town Centre. They were therefore more attractive and command higher prices compared to those offered for the 1st Quarter 1998.

    For the second part of the question, flats in the North-East Zone enjoy greater popularity than flats in the North and West Zones. This is reflected in the higher resale prices of the flats as well as the demand for these flats. In the queue for the new HDB flats, 57% of the applications are for flats in the North-East Zone. In view of this, flats in the North-East Zone are priced relatively higher compared to similar units in the other zones.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, is the Minister saying that if the flats in any specific area are more popular, they will accordingly be priced higher? Is that one of the factors that the HDB prices its flats?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: If an area is more desirable, this should be reflected in the higher land prices. HDB pays for the land price and this would then be reflected in the pricing of the HDB flats and therefore reflect the higher prices.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister when did HDB acquire the land? Was it not acquired many, many years ago? Or was it just recently acquired?

Column: 154



    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The land on which HDB flats are built comes from different sources: some are acquired, some are reclaimed, while some are crown land reverted to the Singapore Government. HDB purchased land from Land Office at the market rate, based on the location, size and density that we are allowed to build. So every year, HDB will buy land from the Land Office and the land prices will reflect the attributes of the site and location.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Minister agree that most of the land for HDB flats was acquired three or four decades ago at a pittance?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The Government has a land bank built up of land from different sources. Let me take an example. Recently, Gillman Camp has been reverted to the Government. Gillman Camp was an old army camp and it is on crown land, so it was given to the Government at $1. Does that mean that we will price the land at $1?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Why not? It is public housing.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: In which case, HDB flats built on Gillman Camp will cost only $100,000 per unit whereas HDB flats built in Jurong West or Punggol which are on reclaimed land and at a very high cost would cost $300,000 or $400,000. How do you then allocate flats in Gillman which would only cost $100,000? The Workers' Party can do that.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: It is not a question of Workers' Party or not. It is a question of properly accounting to the public. How do you arrive at the costs?

    Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, can I remind you not to engage in outbursts of this nature? This is Question Time and you should rise to ask questions.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Is the Minister aware that based on the Internet version of the HDB's final tender results, for Sengkang Neighbourhood 3 Contract 1, Neighbourhood 2 Contract 28 and Contract 27, the average price for building and electrical work is about $88,000 per unit, consisting, I suppose, of 4- and

Column: 155

5-room flats. The average selling price of a 5-room flat, for instance, is about $285,000. Would the Minister explain further and give details as to how HDB flats are being priced? Besides the construction cost, how much is the land cost, and whatever costs like design that command a premium?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: What the Member is quoting probably constitutes the building contracts that we gazette or publicize upon receipt of the tenders. There are several components that go into the pricing of HDB flats. First, the land cost which today constitutes about 50%-60% of the total cost of HDB flats. Secondly, infrastructure to build up the town. Before we go for building contract tender, HDB acts as an agent for Government, putting in the major roads, major sewerage pipes, major water pipes, etc. The Government gives a grant to HDB. So HDB acts like the PWD for the Government, building the roads and all the facilities. Once the land is prepared, then HDB will tender the land. And what the Member is quoting now is the building contract prices. Beyond that, of course, will be the administration cost. HDB also employs architects, project managers, etc. and that would add another 5%-7% of building supervision and administration costs. So that will constitute the total development cost of the HDB flats.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: The Minister mentioned land cost of 50%-60%. Would it not be lower in terms of unit price calculated based on land cost?     Tripartite partnership must be strengthened for the primary reason that the international business world is going to be constantly changing and increasingly competitive.

    Sir, today, I would like to focus my speech on three key areas. The first two will touch on how the PAP Government can further add value to the labour movement and the third area on how the labour movement can further add value to companies.

    As it has been just pointed out by the NMP, life long employability is a key concern of our workers. About 700,000

Column: 175

workers or about 43% of our workforce have at best perhaps a Secondary Two education or less, and many of them are above the age of 40. So they are relatively slower. It would be difficult for them to cope as we become a knowledge-based and IT-plugged economy. Keen competition demands that our workers are trained, retrained and are multi-skilled. Jobs are becoming intertwined and inter-dependent that, for instance, the traditional lines between the blue-collar and white-collar have blurred. Jobs are fast becoming a pale-blue or bluish-white kind of work.

    With the regional economic crisis, the neighbouring countries are becoming significantly more cost competitive. While Singapore can still succeed in attracting higher value added investments and white-collar jobs into Singapore, our problem will be the hastened pace at which low value-added dark blue-collar jobs will disappear. What this means for Singapore, given the lower educational profile of the Singapore workforce is, as Mr Cyrille Tan has pointed out, structural unemployment. We have to take preventive action before it bites our economic jugular veins like a werewolf. Europe has been bitten very badly. Seven out of 10 workers face structural unemployment.

    Nearer home, just look at what has happened to Hong Kong's manufacturing sector. I am not sure whether it is structural unemployment, but it is a very serious job displacement problem. In 1990, the colony's burgeoning manufacturing sector employed more than a million people. Due to restructuring, the manufacturing industry shrunk drastically in 1995 and shed two-thirds of the workers and only employed 350,000 workers. We could potentially face a more serious situation than what the Hong Kong lesson has shown. Smaller economies under the pressure of rising costs due to resource constraints can restructure their industrial base much faster and deeper. Presently, the manufacturing sector's share of Singapore's GDP and employment is 27% and 23% respectively. In other words, GDP

Column: 176

contribution from manufacturing sector, 27%, number of people employed in the manufacturing sector, 23% of the total workforce. Given the lack of focus on skills upgrading and given the present gloom and doom, it is not an unrealistic scenario to imagine the manufacturing employment in the next four years shrinking from 23% of the workforce to 12%, in other words, halving in four years' time, which would result in job losses of at least 200,000 workers.

    This is no glance at the crystal ball. It is a very real, highly likely possibility, if nothing is done. And the workers of Singapore are already starting to see the first signals of the `looming storm'. In yesterday's Business Times, a survey of 100 companies indicates that job security rather than pay now tops workers' concerns. And, Members also must have read yesterday that Seagate Technology, Singapore's second largest private sector employer, will announce major layoffs this week. As industry rumours have it, 20% of its staff will be cut in Singapore and that this is only but the `tip of the iceberg' for all Singapore manufacturing industries.

    Sir, what is most worrying is that the most vulnerable group amongst the 700,000 less-educated Singaporean workers is that more than 220,000 of them are male bread-earners whose household incomes are less than $2,000. These are workers who live in 3-room HDB flats, or maybe 2-room, or 1-room rental flats and they are working as production workers or as cleaners in commerce and services industries.

    Sir, the question that the Members of this House have to ask is: how are these workers going to cope with the storm that is looming when it hits them and their families? And they are no less Singaporeans than all of us in this House. They, and the many more thousands of workers, urgently need the attention of the frontbench, and not just the sympathy of the frontbench or the backbench.

    So the clarion call is for the Government to focus more and invest much more funds on skills redevelopment of the workforce. While Government talks about `Thinking Schools and Learning Nation', it

Column: 177

has given a disproportionately low attention to the education and training of the less educated mid-career adults in our workforce.

    Sir, let me illustrate why. In the Budget for FY 97, there were a combined total of about 470,000 students in our primary and secondary schools. The Government allocated $1.83 billion to educate these 500,000 students. In addition, it allocated $78 million in Edusave bursaries and scholarships and for other scholarships. And it has set aside over a number of years a total of $5 million from our surpluses into the Edusave Endowment Fund.

    In stark contrast, very little has been spent on educating or skilling our workforce. The Government funds worker training mainly through the Skills Development Fund (SDF). In FY 97, it has only disbursed something like $47 million to companies and of this $47 million, $22 million was actually collected through the Skills Development Levy from companies. Perhaps, the Government could have spent a few more millions of dollars here and there through some other training programmes. But that is the amount allocated for worker training.

    Sir, there are 700,000 workers out there with less than eight years of formal education and yet what the Government invests on them sounds like `peanuts' compared to what is invested in our school children. So they say peanuts attract monkeys. Perhaps in good times, the workers may be swinging from job to job, but in bad times, they will have no job to swing to. They may have to swing from tree to tree. Sir, these workers too need schemes like the Edusave. How about initiating `Train-Save' Schemes and training bursaries and scholarships for workers? What about emulating the $5 billion Edusave Endowment Fund with a Worker Training Endowment Fund which could go far beyond the scope of the Skills Development Fund as the SDF has got many limitations.

    Sir, please do not get me wrong about spending money on our children. I support every cent that is spent in

Column: 178

educating our school going children. We must invest on them today to reap the benefits tomorrow. But what I am also saying is that the Government must spend just as much, if not more, and spend it today for workers who missed out on their education yesterday for various reasons. And if we do not do enough for them today, then there may be no tomorrow.

    If the Government is really committed to life-long employability and implementing the concept of life-long learning, it must recognise that it has to go beyond investing in the education of the young. It must develop a comprehensive national infrastructure to develop and coordinate skills upgrading, continuing education and training. It must provide a mechanism, a nexus, beyond the schools for continuation of learning from the school to the workplace. It must provide the flexibility to ensure life-long employability of workers so that it can respond effectively to the changing skill needs of industry and business. It must provide incentives and motivation for workers to want to upgrade and learn a new skill even in good times.

    It is with great hope, anxiety and high expectations that the workers look forward to the establishment of the Ministry of Manpower, as announced by our Prime Minister. It is also our hope that the new Ministry will coordinate the work of various agencies to develop a comprehensive continuing education infrastructure. A wide range of Government-funded programmes that allow for modular learning, and the accumulation of training credits leading up to various levels of national certification should be conceptualised, implemented and coordinated. A tripartite National Training Committee needs to be formed to coordinate these efforts and to provide feedback. Schemes like the ITE's Company On-the-Job Training Centre (COJTC) and NTUC's Skills Redevelopment Programme must be strengthened and beefed up to become national programmes. And as I have said earlier, Edusave concepts must be extended into Train-Save Schemes for workers.

Column: 179



    Sir, in short, we need a paradigm shift in the way that we look at continuing education and skills upgrading. We need to take a holistic approach to succeed. We need the Government to act and act fast. We in the labour movement keenly await the formation of the Ministry of Manpower.

Symbiotic relationship between PAP and NTUC

    Sir, I now like to move on to the second area in which the Government can further add value to the labour movement and that is the symbiotic relationship between the PAP and the NTUC.

    Sir, the PAP has always had the support of workers. In fact, trade unionists were amongst the convenors of the Party. At the inauguration of the PAP, most of those who were present were union members. Half the Protem Committee were trade unionists. Once in power in 1959, the PAP Government set about to implement its election pledges - to strengthen the labour movement. Laws were passed to check employers from taking advantage of workers. Trade unions were given their rightful place in society.

    In 1961, the labour movement was split into two, with one group (the NTUC) backing the PAP and the other supporting Barisan Sosialis. The NTUC stood shoulder-to-shoulder with the PAP in the struggle against colonialism, then against communism and, subsequently, against communalism. It is this symbiotic relationship that has enabled us to weather the storms in earlier decades. With the support of organised labour, the Government has been able to take tough decisions to overcome one crisis after another. Let me state here and now that we in the labour movement stand fully behind the Government as it takes steps to minimise the impact of the regional currency crisis.

    One may ask why this unflinching support. Because the workers know that their destiny and that of the nation depends on good and effective government. Without good government,

Column: 180

we could not have full employment, 90% home ownership, universal education, medical and other social benefits. But I am afraid that a growing number of younger Singaporeans take this good life for granted, and this good relationship for granted. The old guards in the NTUC and the PAP have made way for younger leaders who have not gone through the same experiences in tackling life-and-death issues. So will the symbiotic relations betweeen the PAP and NTUC remain strong in the years ahead?

    As Mr Cyrille Tan has mentioned, we have to continually nurture this special partnership which is so unique to us and not take chances. Last Sunday, the Secretary-General of the PAP, PM Goh has called for closer ties between the PAP and the NTUC. This call has certainly reassured the labour movement of the continued commitment of the PAP and particularly under the younger leadership.

    Sir, I would like now to move to this area where unions can add value to companies. While we pride ourselves in having the world's best workforce, there is still tremendous scope for improvement. One area where we lag behind as a nation, especially as seen in the BERI survey, is in workers' attitudes. Workers' attitudes are shaped largely by the workplace relationship with management and therefore the level of their motivation.

    We have an excellent working relationship at the top level, between the CEOs of companies and the NTUC leaders. But the area that needs further strengthening is at the middle level and at the workplace where better rapport needs to be built between branch union officials and the middle management. Greater effort is needed to build mutual trust and understanding. We need to develop shared vision and show that if the relationship is stoked the right way, the unions can galvanize the workforce to contribute significantly and add much, much more value to the companies.

    On the part of the unions, there is a need to perhaps review the traditional way that we do things and conduct negotiations. In Japan, for example, the

Column: 181

collective bargaining process which is done in the months of spring is called the "Spring Offensive". It sounds very confrontational and I am sure Mr Matthias Yao will agree that it sounds like a military maneouvre. While collective agreements (CAs) still serve a very important role for unionised workers, we have to change the modus operandi. For example, a collective agreement (CA) is a document that captures what compensation and benefits that the company will provide for the workers. But, in my opinion, it is one sided. Time has come for us to move from collective agreements to partnership agreements - from CAs to PAs. A partnership agreement can go beyond the CA and include the commitment of the union and workers to a shared vision and add value to the company. One of the key ways in which unions can add value to the company that they work for is through productivity improvement.

    While there are many scientific ways in which we can approach productivity improvement, to me, the fundamental factor that contributes to productivity is human attitude. The right work attitudes of staff can do wonders in enhancing productivity. Therefore, if branch unions and management can forge a closer working partnership, there can be so much more value added to companies.

    The NTUC and the PSB have set up a task force to find ways for unions to add value to their companies. The NTUC will move its emphasis from productivity awareness to developing an integrated and action-oriented approach to push productivity at the unionised workplace. These could include training, quality action programmes, job redesign and enlargement. The details of these programmes will be announced in due course.

    Finally, Sir, let us reaffirm our commitment to tripartism in the light of the present regional scenario. The most scintillating views on the kaleidoscope are obtained in brilliant sunlight. With sunlight, the views sparkle and gleam. Similarly, in boom times, the tripartite relationship is obviously working well. In the absence of sunlight, the patterns of

Column: 182

colour and light are still a fascinating sight in the kaleidoscope, because the mirrors are still reflecting all available light off each other. The economic climate that we are in now is like the weak rays of sunshine. The financial and currency turmoil in the region is casting a shadow of pessimism and caution. The situation that we are in now is all the more needy of a tripartite partnership so that the three partners can reflect and bring out the best in each other, to create a beautiful pattern, a lovely society. In the absence of a strong sunlight, when the economy is down, we must ensure that the mirrors of tripartism pick up the best of colours, hues, brilliance and intensity of productivity, so that we can yield the maximum of benefit for the worker, employer and nation as a whole.

    Sir, I support the motion.

    The Minister without Portfolio (Mr Lim Boon Heng): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion.

    The first concern of the NTUC, as Mr Cyrille Tan put it, is: how can trade unions add value to their members and to the tripartite partners? Really, the fundamental question is: how can trade unions remain relevant? To remain relevant, trade unions will have to add value to workers, employers and to society at large. It cannot keep on doing what it used to do, but to do what is useful today and in the years ahead.

    The success of any movement depends on the quality of its leaders. We have been fortunate that our unions have thrown up good leaders. In the past, unions could draw from more than 90% of the workforce for members, and hence leaders. In 1970, 84% of all workers at best had primary school education. Today, that same group of workers with that kind of qualification has shrunk to 39%, which means the rest have better education. That has been the success story of Singapore. And drawing from that, if the traditional way in which we think about union membership remains the same, then unions must draw from a poorer pool of members or grassroots leaders. So the difference between the past leaders who still continue today and what we may

Column: 183

draw on in the future would be the quality. If we are going to have the same balanced relationship that we have had all these years, then we should re-examine the scope of union representation.

    The biggest worry today, as Mr Cyrille Tan and Mr Sinnakaruppan said, is whether our workers will remain employed throughout their active working life. This is the second key concern mentioned by Mr Cyrille Tan. Conventional thinking is that it is the duty of the State to educate the young to the best of their ability, until they go to work. Thereafter, further education, or upgrading of skills is the responsibility of the individual, or his employer. With faster technological change, is this still valid? Each worker now has to re-learn skills three to five times in his working life. The cost of keeping workers employable with relevant skills throughout their working lives has gone up.

    Just now, Mr Sinnakaruppan mentioned that the Government through the SDF spent only $47 million in 1996. That is not the full story. For every dollar which the SDF funds, another $10 is paid for either by the employer or the individual. So our total spending on continuing education and training today is more of the order of $400 million to $500 million. And yet this is not enough. Therefore, the cost of upgrading the skills of our workers in the light of the changes around us will be very, very high. So this means that we cannot rely on old thinking about how we deal with continuing education and training. There should be a central agency to plan the manpower needs of the economy, coordinate a national infrastructure for skills upgrading, and to devise programmes to support the individual and the employers. Without this, we will be trapped in the rut.

    Workers will say that they do not know what courses to take up, or that they have no time for training, since they have to earn a living. On the other hand, the employers will say that they cannot afford to train if the worker will leave for some other employer at the end of the training.

Column: 184

In this period of uncertainty, there will be a natural tendency to cut back on spending. To the employers, I say, "Don't cut back on training." If you do so, you will be making a big mistake. Of course, you can make training more cost effective, but we should not stop training and upgrading. It is the quality of the workforce that will give you the cutting edge in competition. And one more point: It is not enough to train only the young. You need to train the not-so-young and also the old.

    Training has to be a national effort, a shared responsibility. We need to find more effective ways of upgrading and channeling workers from the declining sectors (for example, consumer electronics) to new growth sectors like wafer fabrication. If not, Singaporean workers will become under-employed while new growth sectors will be overly dependent on foreign skilled workers. This is not desirable. It is also not sustainable.

    Look at the structural unemployment in Europe. New jobs have been created, but large numbers of workers do not have the skills that these jobs require. Each government knows that retraining has to be done, if structural unemployment is to be overcome. But money is scarce. And even the billions of dollars they squeeze out of tight budgets will make only a small difference. This is the price they pay for the past thinking that the upgrading of skills is the responsibility of the individual and the employers. It is now a problem for the Government, and there is just not enough money. If we take care of the continuous retraining of workers now, whilst we can afford it, then the development of new sectors in our economy will be successful, because our workers will truly feel that it has all been done for their benefit.

    Therefore, I welcome the proposal to expand the functions of the Ministry of Labour into a Ministry of Manpower. When there is a lead agency to deal with the matter, then the individual efforts of different agencies will move forward in the right direction. Workers will know that there is a Ministry looking after the development of our own workers. It will be a clear focal point. Continuing education

Column: 185

and training will then be coordinated. Our workers' skills will be upgraded continuously, so they will remain employed as we bring in new investments. Otherwise, some may think the policies we are putting in place to attract new growth sectors are for the benefit of foreign workers.

    Yes, as we move more and more into the knowledge-based economy, we need more knowledge workers. What is more, we need a critical mass of skilled workers in a sector before it can take off. So we need foreign talent.

    Take, for example, the financial services sector. If we are to grow the business in new financial services, we must build up a critical mass of expertise, with a heavy injection of foreign talent. It is one thing to look at this from the macro view. What is the impact, seen from the perspective of the individual Singaporean? Let me cite an example from the financial services sector. Just a few days ago, a couple of employees in this sector told me that some Singaporeans feel marginalised, or sidelined. A foreign boss will recruit more foreigners, and Singaporeans are shut out. There does not seem to be a transfer of expertise. We should expect such problems. A critical mass of talent versed in new areas has to be built up from recruiting foreigners. The volume of business at the start is not large, so they do not employ so many Singaporeans. Singaporeans do not seem to be given a role. They have yet to be trained in the skills. It is only when the business volume grows big enough that Singaporeans will be brought into the business. So on the one hand, we need to explain to Singaporeans what to expect, and at the same time monitor to ensure that competent Singaporeans are also given the chance.

    We should also be aware of social problems when large numbers of foreign workers from the same source country are concentrated in one place. I am not referring only to Orchard Road or Serangoon Road, but also in the factories. They tend to stick together as a social group. This leads to friction between foreign workers and Singaporean

Column: 186

workers, in the same factory. Fortunately, these problems are not serious so far. But we should be mindful.

    In view of the turbulence in the East Asian economies, there is some fear among Singaporeans of lay-offs. Yesterday morning, as Mr Sinnakaruppan said, for the first time one of our papers reported, in a long while, that the key concern of our employees is now job security. Little wonder. We read in the newspapers that over two million Indonesians have lost their jobs as a result of the current crisis. They may be joined by another million whom Malaysia intends to send home. Unemployment in Malaysia itself among Malaysians is also expected to rise. There are already more than a million unemployed in Thailand. Another million jobs will be lost in Korea through the restructuring required to restore its economy back to health. When our workers read or hear of such problems, naturally they are a little bit worried.

    Quite naturally, employers are concerned about prospects in the coming months. Management will be thinking of strategies for survival. How to weather the next year or two and cost will have to be trimmed. One option is to retrench workers. We have faced such situations before. We have worked together to overcome problems. What is more, we have also put in place systems which should allow us to face downturns with less human cost. Companies should thus be better prepared to cope with the downturn. We did this through the practice of tripartism. Let us not forget that.

    What did we put in place, as a result of the last recession? We wanted a system which should allow employers to reduce wage cost without having to resort to retrenchment as a first measure. We have put in place the flexi-wage system. What is this flexi-wage system? In the flexi-wage system, there are two basic components: the monthly wage and the variable bonuses. The variable bonuses should make up about 20% of the total annual wage. So in a downturn the company can reduce annual wage cost by up to 20% and still pay their workers the

Column: 187

full monthly wage. Employers should therefore trim wage cost by reducing the variable bonus before they consider retrenchment. We put in place a flexi-wage system, not a flexi-worker system, to allow companies to cope with downturns. It is cut wage cost first, not cut workers first. Unions accept that retrenchment is a management prerogative. But if after working with employers to implement the flexi-wage system, employers do not use it, but resort to retrenchment when the company shows losses for the first time in one quarter, it will not be fair to workers and the unions who represent them. If in making use of the flexi-wage system and other cost cutting measures are still not enough, then we can accept retrenchment to keep the company viable and to save jobs. So I urge all employers not to resort to retrenchment at the first sign of trouble. If we have to accept retrenchment, who goes first?

    It is popular to say that in a downturn, the foreigners should be retrenched first. But when a company has to retrench, it should retain the best team, to be competitive. So when it comes to deciding who should go, we should adopt the following:

    Between two persons, the one who is clearly better than the other stays while the weaker one is retrenched. If the better worker is a foreigner, the Singaporean is retrenched. If the better worker is Singaporean, then the foreign worker goes. If both are equally good, then the Singaporean stays and the foreign worker goes. This is a sound basis to protect the jobs remaining. Most of these jobs will be held by Singaporeans.

    Retrenchment, we hope, will be a short term problem. The well-being of our workers depends on our ability to attract new investments. It has to be knowledge intensive, and high value-added investments. We have to be more productive to overcome our lack of a large domestic market and lack of natural resources. That is why closer cooperation among the three social partners will be more important. Our past success in attracting

Column: 188

investments is not something we can take for granted. The competition today is much more intense than it has ever been. We are competing with developed countries for high end investments. We have to make Singapore a profitable place to do business despite our lack of a large domestic market and our lack of natural resources.

    To be a valued partner of employers, our unions must continue to do what they have done well in the past: working with employers to foster a harmonious industrial relations climate, and ensuring that the labour market remains flexible and workers employable, as my colleagues have said.

    Maintaining a flexible labour market means the critical re-examination of hard-won terms of employment. We cannot assume that what we put in place in the past are still right today. We cannot assume that they have not become rigidities that make our labour market less flexible than other economies. It will not be easy to discard these hard-won terms of employment. Some of these may have been regarded in the past as essential to prevent employers from exploiting workers. So how can such terms be varied or modified without allowing abuse? That is a question together we must address.

    Trade unions can also add value to employers through helping to implement programmes to raise productivity - skills upgrading, promotion of Quality Circles, setting up Total Quality Management Programmes, 5S programmes, and suggestions schemes.

    When we do this, we will not be the only union movement which helps management, although conventional wisdom may think otherwise. Toyota, for example, acknowledged in the 1980s that it was union support that helped them to develop what they called the Toyota Production System, a highly regarded system which other car manufacturers wanted to also put in place. Toyota knows that it is through the years of close working relationship between management and unions and workers that makes the system possible. So it is not

Column: 189

easy for any other company to replicate. So Toyota welcomes GM and the like to look at their system. This shows how at least in one company, management regards cooperation with the union as a critical factor for success.

    Under our present circumstances, union support for management is most important today in the area of reducing unit costs, to enhance competitiveness and then it will make a difference to how well we weather the storm ahead. The NTUC and the unions aim to be a valued partner of employers. When the companies are profitable, then jobs are secure, and the economy as a whole benefits.

    In what other ways can unions add value to society? In the past 30 years, the labour movement had embarked on two major programmes. The first is the development of the cooperative movement, which has benefited consumers, especially the consumers from the working class. The second is in bringing social and recreational facilities previously enjoyed only by the higher income within the means of the lower income.

    In the years ahead, there are two areas where our unions can play a social role. The first concerns the aging population. This will create new needs, such as the care for the elderly. With smaller families and nuclear families, the lower income will require help most, because both husband and wife have got to go to work. Such assistance will fall outside the scope of volunteer welfare organisations. The labour movement can, and should, play a part, with support from the other two social partners.

    The second area is the effects of globalisation. Globalisation means that the labour market becomes more competitive, indeed a global one. High end wages will be set by the world-wide shortage of such talent, whilst the low-skilled wages will be depressed by the overwhelming surplus of this group of workers. This widening of the wage gap can create social problems. It can create social tensions. So far, we avoided those problems. Why? Because our education, health and housing policies

Column: 190

have kept the real net gap narrower than if let to pure market forces. You take housing - a perennial subject of debate in this House. Our home ownership policy has given each one a roof over their heads, and nine out of 10 own their homes they live in. We take this for granted now. But this is one reason why we do not have people sleeping on the sidewalks, as the jobless do in the cities of the developed nations. For Singaporeans who have been prudent with their home buying decisions, they need not fear being turned out into the streets through unemployment. You see in the developed countries, a high proportion of rent accommodation. When they lose their jobs and cannot pay the rent, the landlord who is from the private sector will demand the keys back to their apartments. That is why every winter you have photographs of people sleeping on the sidewalks in New York. We should build on what we have built up so far and try to narrow the wealth gap further. So, in this, we will have to be more creative to ensure that the asset enhancement programme benefits the lower income.

    Unions can play a role and add value to society with the continued support of employers and Government. But will this close partnership built up over the past 20 years last - a question which Mr Sinnakaruppan asked. Will it grow stronger? This will depend on what each of the social partners does.

    The partnership between the NTUC and the PAP Government is built on personal relationships, on trust, on shared beliefs and shared goals.

    However, at each general election, there is leadership renewal in the PAP Government. We also have leadership renewal in the unions through periodic elections. Personal relationships cannot be handed from one generation to another. It has to be forged anew by the successors. Therefore, to keep tripartism strong, the interaction among leaders of the PAP Government and the NTUC and the unions has to be managed. It takes time for trust to develop. Therefore, we welcome the Prime Minister's suggestion on Sunday that joint seminars for the PAP be held with the NTUC. It is as much an

Column: 191

opportunity for the PAP to better understand the workers as it is for union leaders to influence PAP leaders who form the Government so that national policies remain pro-worker. Strengthen the links, and we can be assured that the working relationship, which has been one of our unique strengths as a country, will continue well into the next century.

    For now, quite clearly the key concern of everyone is how soon the current economic problems in the region will be resolved. These problems are external but they affect us. To solve this problem, international cooperation is critical. Let us hope that there will be close cooperation and the will to accept the remedies however painful they may be.

    Our response internally, in our country, must be to follow what we have done before. We have weathered different crises before, through everyone pulling together. We overcame the 1985-86 recession through the practice of tripartite cooperation. Now is the time to reinforce this.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Mr Speaker, Sir, at the outset, let me first state that I have been a member of the National Wages Council for two years. The NWC is one of the key instruments of tripartism in Singapore and I have therefore had the opportunity to observe the workings of tripartite partnership at first hand.

    I would like to make four points.

    The first point I would like to make is that I agree that tripartism has been a key competitive advantage. It is one of the main socio-economic institutions that has contributed to peaceful industrial relationship in Singapore and has helped to achieve labour market reforms in order to lower the cost of doing business and increase productivity. This tripartite partnership has served Singapore well in three respects. The good industrial relations that we have had in Singapore cannot just be attributed to our labour laws alone which permit workers to strike only after recourse to arbitration. Rather it is due to the meeting of minds of unions,

Column: 192

business and Government representatives, achieved after considerable discussions and negotiations. This tradition of dialogue is now well established in Singapore. Its anchor is the NWC which meets intensively for several months each year principally to negotiate wage increases. In its 25 years of existence, the NWC has indeed contributed significantly towards peaceful industrial relations in Singapore.

    Third, NTUC and tripartism have also been instrumental in encouraging labour market reforms, such as the switch from fixed to flexible wages that Minister Lim Boon Heng mentioned, and in raising the retirement age from 60 to 62. It is often difficult to change established practices. But tripartism has enabled these adaptations to be made to the Singapore labour system for the good of workers and employers alike.
